You get the whole package when you hold a reception here and the bill came out to less than what we had estimated since we only payed for what was ordered and BC was very honest with adding up the bill counting only the ordered food and drink from the open bar.   It was just perfect! Thank you Ramon, Welut, Karwan and everyone else at Bocce Cafe for making our wedding day so wonderful!

czm7XP8JnNnaDYnFXUjkvg.review_text: We went there for lunch yesterday.  Bocce is a Italian restauant in North Beach with no Italian beers  on tap.  But no stars against them for that.  Probably most Italian restaurants do not have Italian beers on tap.  So I asked for a Peroni at the bar.  They gave me a bottle that had chunks of dirt on it.  When they opened it, the overflow washed away the dirt, but now there is a 1/4 of a beer and dirt all over the bar.  When I asked for a glass for the beer, they gave me a tumbler.  The food was alright.  The salad had way too much dressing, it made all of our faces pucker after we ate it.  Majority of the Steak sandwich was fat.  The Tiramisu was the best part of lunch, but the coffee tasted like coffee filters.

QU4kr1-uMtZgy8i_VSlfrw.review_text: What a shame.  Bocce has a location that would otherwise work for them if their reputation for not-so-great food didn't precede them.  Their front entrance and dining patio are beautiful; unfortunately, no other patrons but my co-workers and I were there to enjoy it during lunchtime.  I wondered why it was so empty, and I learned the reason a little over halfway through my meal--when I found an aluminum can shaving in my gnocchi.

e53RP4gmdVprMPiH8reKBw.review_text: After reading the menu for Bocce Cafe online we thought that it would be the ideal place for our 13 people group to have dinner.  When we walked in I was a bit concerned that our nine teens would be too loud, rowdy, and perhaps too brown for the other diners.  However, the staff made us *all* feel welcome at Bocce, the menu was easy for the teens to maneuver and the portions were perfectly sized - I don't think anyone had leftovers and everybody was full at the end of the night.  Everyone was able to order easily for under $10/person - considering how great the food was, this was a small miracle.  I do wish that the music hadn't been quite so loud so that it would have been much easier to hear everyone - but it did help the other patrons enjoy their meals, I'm sure.  The gnocci was particularly amazing and I'm still craving those little morsels from heaven!

J8X3xtFXhx_VOER6LFcn4Q.review_text: Warm place on a rainy night with a ski lodgey feeling. Cheapest italian dinners in North Beach, and plenty of pasta sauce options. Feta, tomatoes, and olive sauce was delish, but service was slow, and wine was unremarkable.

E9m9adcWg9h8mRX9idm9Qw.review_text: 3 cheers for mediocrity! But 2 stars for yelp.  This place has a nice backyard outdoor/indoor patio-type area, and is good if you have a group of 40 people who want to be loud and fed cheap, basic Italian food. Outside of those parameters, I wouldn't take someone here I wanted to impress, even on a budget.  BTW, where the hell are the bocce ball courts? That would definitely improve the entertainment factor here, and secure another star or two.   Not to mention be true to its name. Ciao.

k3wjSI44_hXgqMiYHqah7g.review_text: With so many other great choices in little italy we ended up here by accident...or rather by elimination process. We were starving, it was Saturday late lunch, and most delicious places were closed for the period between 2-5. After entering a few establishments (like Sports Cafe that smelled like an alley way behind a chinese restaurant) we were left with only Bocce Cafe...and as the guys were getting cranky we knew it was crucial that we stuff food down their throats ASAP.   First impression of this place (as mentioned by almost tons of other yelpers) is great. Their inside dining space is great - crazy tall ceiling, windows, and rustic furniture makes this a great evening spot. However, it was a beautiful sunny Saturday so we opted for the courtyard - so pretty out here. Clearly this has been around for a long time because vines drape the walls and there are trees providing shade. This part of the restaurant is fantastic.   We ordered the potato soup (pretty good but nothing that makes it stand out or makes you come back for it), linguini pescatore with white wine sauce (this dish had potential b.c. the pasta itself was good but they clearly didn't let everything cook long enough because the flavor was lacking BIG time...the wine wasn't cooked down as necessary and they forgot either garlic or herbs...can't put my finger one which one), the shrimp pizza (this item was tasty BUT I warn you that the crust is not pizza crust...it's like a bread crust...weird and kind of disappointing but all the other ingredients rocked), monicatti (the yummiest of all dishes! sooo good), and the ciappino (this was actually really really good and came with a pretty generous side of pasta).   As you can see everything was good but very few items were GOOD. Also, the fresh bread that they bring you is not italian at all...basic white. That along with the pizza crust made me give this place 3 stars...just not authentic enough even though it has the atmosphere.

LbDZ2y1-13W148ZboQnZnA.review_text: The setup of the place is cool.  My pasta was more like a soup though...and our waitress...well she was a bit off.  I asked her if they took AMEX...she said "yes...even the black AMEX".

E0Tn9i-nBYc7Le4iVwi14g.review_text: Basically an overpriced Olive Garden.  My boyfriend brought me here for Valentine's Day. I will say that the patio and ambiance is charming. Also, there is an awesome cat on the patio whose presence basically made my night.   BUT, the buck stops there. The food was ATROCIOUS. Cheap. Inauthentic. Poorly made. None of the pasta was homemade. I was advised by our server to order a pasta dish that has prawns in it and described as "tomatoes, white wine and garlic" as the sauce. I specifically do not eat cream sauces, so I am very careful to not order them. My boyfriend ordered the Gnocchi with pesto sauce.  We get our food - first, none of the pasta is homemade (amazing to me that a restaurant in San Francisco can even exist and charge $15 - $25 a plate without homemade pasta) . His pesto sauce was a cream sauce.... My "tomato and white whine with garlic" also turns out to be a cream sauce. It's heavy, WAY overly sauced, oily and disgusting. I called over one of the servers to explain that I didn't realize that it was a cream sauce dish because it wasn't listed on the menu. He immediately argues with me to say it was. I try to state that cream sauce wasn't in the description, despite being clearly marked in other dishes. He tells me I'm wrong. Eventually, I have to ask him to just bring over our main server, who also proceeds to tell me I am wrong.  He asks me what I would like instead - I answer capellini pomodoro  - a dish that is usually made with a sauce of light olive oil, tomatoes, garlic and basil. It's a pretty common dish, not hard to do well. Instead of bringing what I ask for; he says the chef made something else for me - it is linguini with prawns in a VERY.... I repeat... VERY heavy butter sauce made with white wine. It's DISGUSTING. It's so heavy that I can't eat it. At this point, I can't even ask them to take it back because my boyfriend finished eating about 45 minutes prior, that I just eat the tomatoes and the shrimp - leaving ALL of the pasta and that nasty, nasty sauce.   This was a huge disappointment, especially when our bill for 2 people was about $100, and I left hungry. The food was something I would expect to see on Kitchen Nightmares or something. Great Italian food does not have to be covered in heavy cream or butter to be considered good - anyone who has actually been to Italy will tell you that the best Italian food usually has neither cream nor butter.  Further, I actually picked up a copy of their menu on the way out to double check and see if either of our food choices mentioned that they were served with cream. They do not, and I have the menu to prove it. It is NOT appropriate to argue with a customer, especially when the server doesn't even know what the menu actually says.   I hope to NEVER, ever go back. I'm disappointed from the experience (with the exception of the charming cat) to the point that I wish we had asked for our money back. Such a shame to waste a perfectly good Valentine's day on this place.

GCuDiPUKYxhgFHP5LqJa2Q.review_text: 3.5 stars  Having been to another bocce place in the south bay, I thought I know what to expect so we never got around to check out this place.  Recently, we decided to walk through the trellis walkway and check out the place.  A quick look at the dining room and we knew we will return.    We did on a recent Friday night looking for a light snack.  It was around 9:30pm and the place was about 1/3 full.  The jazz trio was still there doing their last few songs - we appreciate the live music but you really can't hear the singer as her voice was not strong enough and also wasn't very clear.  We were sat at one of the corner booths with large fluffy pillows - that's one of the main reasons why we came, the ambiance is just cozy with the soft lighting and these comfy seatings.  It's also nice to see the twinkling lights lit on the outside - we can imagine how enjoyable it can be on a warm summer night.    Service was attentive, overly attentive to a point where you think perhaps they want you to leave.    Anyway, we had a glass of wine and decided to have the appetizer for 2 - a sampling of some of the antipasti: mozzarella caprese, smoked salmon, bruschetta, olives, roasted bell peppers, grilled vegetables, marinated baby artichokes, prosciutto and salami.  The grilled vegetables were 2 slices each of eggplants and zucchini.  The best was the bruschetta, the prosciutto was dry, the smoked salmon a bit too salty...    The price is pretty good, maybe that's why it attracts so many families.  Will likely return to try their pasta or something and enjoy their comfy seatings.

AwQISaMsBGaaTkKaHRt3ZA.review_text: Excellent food and great atmosphere!  The staff were great as well.  The only problem is that there is little parking in the area, and when it's busy, you have to use valet or walk quite a distance.  Once inside, it is great!!  I would return again in a second!

krAZx244NwotB8CkI5jyag.review_text: I loved this place!!! One of my best friends n I came here for nye n we fell in love. We can't wait to go back.  The food was good, the service was good, and the ambiance was good, we couldn't have ask for a better start to our night...

uK8w_LkfsNXKlBC1a_uhQA.review_text: So we went here as the finish line to our treasure hunt on Saturday. Our large group took a while to sit, but since we had to leave early to get a CalTrain back down to South Bay, we managed to sit. Our team leader had had his wedding rehearsal here, so he knew some of the staff, and got us seated quickly and the waiter allowed my wife and I to order early, before the rest of the group had even gotten seated. That was very considerate, especially since our total group was like 45 people.   My chicken lasagna was delicious - but my usual issue with restaurant lasagna applies: the serving is just not quite enough. My wife had the penne with vodka sauce and ate it up yum. Combined with the delicious warm herbed bread that came as an appetizer to dip in olive oil, it almost filled me up. Perhaps if we had time for dessert....  Since it was rainy out, our crowd tried to squeeze inside the entry area, which got really crowded. Even with half the people spilling all around the bar area, it was too crowded.   If I ever find myself in the North Beach area and looking to have some good Italian food, i'd come back here.

4RQ6mrPg_IzJr2V-g0BRew.review_text: Talk about stumbling on to a hidden gem.  While over in North Beach on a recent rainy friday night, we happend to hear from some folks who had jsut eaten at Bocce and suggested we try it as well.  Im glad they did. Its got a great quirky, old-world feel to it, yet provides incredible food and live music. the resturant itself is down a romantic path, off the main drag of North Beach and opens up into a huge, hihg cielings farm like room.  the pals I was with both got the Chicken parm. crisp and tender, with out being too bready, the sauce they use was definately like homestyle  ones not to sweet or spicy. I had the cioppino (fsih stew) and was pretty impressed. Nicely cooked, great flavors. I might have wanted it a bit spicier for my pesonal taste - but I cant fault them with that.  The staff are nice, polite and pretty attentive, but I wouldnt say they were particularly "friendly or welcoming" but given it was a busy night I didnt expect false friendlyness...( now maybe after  I've gone a dozen times I might like to see some smiles). They run pretty proficiently - also most to the piont where its too proficeint , in a  casual place I generally like to feel Im not the next table to turn.  Over all  - I'd say check'em out.  We didnt try the fried squid - but from what I could see at the table next to us - nicely prepared and didnt smell fishy from over used frying oil

3U4sIMyI9Iax2X8GRr4eog.review_text: Found this place to be a nice surprise on a Friday night in a fairly busy / overrun stretch of NB. Secluded space with an outdoor patio, reasonably priced food and wine, and very attentive and polite staff. Was enjoying a pretty tasty pasta sampler plate at the bar, when things took a turn for the worst.  All the sudden, someone jumps on a mic and begins giving a speech to in the neighborhood of 50 Germans, all part of a visiting orchestra, the sound of which dominates the dining space. Turns out they basically have a semi-private party occupying 2/3 of the main dining area. There is deafening yelling and applause at the end of the speech, and it is hard to have a conversation with the person next to you while the speech is going on, let alone during the ovations that follow. At the completion of the speech, the mic is passed to someone else. REPEAT 10+ times. This went on for about 30 minutes and was continuing when we left.   As a customer at a nice restaurant, I would expect notice before dining that this was going to be going on. Something along the lines of, "Sir, we have a large party in attendance tonight, and I'd like to let you know that it may at times be very loud." Or, at the very least, an acknowledgement at some point from someone (apology, something on the house, etc.) that this was unexpected and likely very detrimental to our dining experience.   Instead, they tried to carry on as if this was "business as usual." I left with a headache and will not be coming back.

Kb4prI_ulN4UCi8sZfVDoA.review_text: Pricy but I liked the food a lot. Actually, it was the first time that enjoyed italian food, and not only mine but the samples of other friends. I would definitely go there again. about price, in end of the day, I paid 31 $ for a beer + a delicious pasta with Vodka in it + tea + tip and tax. By the way, the environment  and live jazz was  great

4JuSRnKMwJFPA7pDOi7MCg.review_text: Good ol' standby. We took our daughter to lunch for her birthday. It was a nice day so we were able to sit out on the patio. We were welcomed by the neighborhood cat.   (It's friendly but doesn't bother you.) I can tell you that you will want to watch out for falling figs. At this time of year, they were dropping onto the patio quite regularly. We ordered carpaccio for a starter, and a bottle of Chianti. Our main dishes consisted of Cannelloni, Ravioli and Ravioli alla Spinaci. We liked our meal and we liked our server.  No complaints here. We have always ate lunch at Bocce, never dinner.  Our daughter told us that she had been at Bocce for dinner on a live music night and it was way too hard to hear your dinner companion talk.  Just something to think about.  Maybe that's a good thing...

AqBNpXElwesY8zwGXQ2xbA.review_text: I really wanted to like this place! The pros are all in the aesthetic of the place. This place is set back from the main street, bringing the customer through a mini ally that beautifully decorated by plants and greenery. Once the customer is inside they are pleasantly surprised by the lodge-lime decor (lots of beautifully constructed wood ceilings and beams, dim lights, fireplaces). They even have an outdoor garden seating area. Servers are friendly.   The major CON is the food. It suppose to be Italian but very lackluster. I ordered the ravioli and it tasted just lime chef boredee.  Bring in a good Italian chef to revamp the menu and maybe I'll come back!

qa04NQ2wr6G2YVQ_GOEv1g.review_text: Came here for lunch. Ordered a gnocchi after  reading someone's review. Also ordered fried calamari.. Lets see  Gnocchi- aka the potato dumplings slaater in pesto cheesy sauce... wayyy to heavy. I have like 5... and was turned off by it. I brought it home, and it ended in the garbage... =(  But, the calamari was made to perfection  Its a nice little hidden treasure. Gotta check it out.

d-11tFJafg-RzG8PYRk4LQ.review_text: Went there just last night.  We were seated at a two-top with one seat being a couch, my girlfriend loved this and it allowed us to sit close and comfortable together on the same side while I enjoyed a glass of wine. This was a great start to our meal.   The bread was served and we absolutely loved the two types of bread with the olive oil/balsamic/garlic mixture for dipping.   The dinning room was loud, but this to me added to the experience...afterall it's Italian!  It was more festive, than just plain loud which is a better way to describe it.   The only reason I only give 4 stars is because of the service. It wasn't bad, it was just inattentive. We didn't need too much during the night and I was easily able to flag down our server, but basically if I didn't motion to her she didn't stop by after the initial order taking and check drop.  Service could have been much more attentive and engaging.

3uhNmu9HtIcpUj4F1wnwog.review_text: Love love love this restaurant!  It is good for groups, date night, whatever.  The food is delicious (try their gnocchi & their eggplant parmesean).  Seriously so good.  And not expensive either.  It can get a little loud is the only drawback, but well worth the food, location & cost!

aqQ0MR0a9Ht9srz7PTRE3g.review_text: After my first experience at Bocce, I ended up coming two nights in a row. It is definitely one of my favorite restaurans in North Beach, and now one of my favorites in the city...so the negative reviews really surprise me! I'm here to show Bocce some love.   Bocce is tucked away off Green Street and from the outside, does not appear to be anything worth getting excited over. You have to walk down a little path to reach the restaurant, making it feel like a cabin or something.   Bocce is spacious and warm, both ideal for large groups and cozy enough for intimate dates or dinners with friends. We were seated at one of the tables with couches in the center of the restaurant--perfect. Bocce was magical that night, I don't know why anyone would say otherwise about the ambiance. It's adorable and fun, with live music playing on weekend nights and festive decorations all around.  The bar looked hopping as well. So after being won over by the ambiance and the service, which I must add was great, I held my breath as our food arrived. I feared Bocce would disappoint and my newly discovered restaurant would let me down.  The food was good!!! I think it's hard to go wrong with pasta, but Bocce really delivered. I also want to add that in North Beach it can be difficult to find a restaurant that's on the reasonable end in terms of pricing, many places seem very expensive for what you get. Bocce had good portion sizes and was fairly priced.  The dessert was goooood. Definitely order the tiramisu for something on the lighter end or the chocolate cake if you want something rich.   I cannot rave enough about Bocce. It really is adorable, cozy and fun. The live music is a great touch but there's something about the space that makes you feel right at home. I have to disagree with the less-than-stellar reviews and say that I really found Bocce to be a delight, and will certainly be back for many dinners to come.

2iSBJHVMNsolJ3AH1g_D7A.review_text: I like how this place is tucked away in the back of some building. It has a really nice patio for warm days.  The portions are huge, the food is good, and the prices are very reasonable. Sure bet for some real italian food.  Very easy to walk by, so make sure you don't miss it.

ca0N3Fl3FckAWyupp6sDgQ.review_text: I've been going to this place on and off over the last 10 years or so (but before my most recent visit I hadn't been since 2002), so I think it's high time that I review it.  Bocce Cafe is not the best at anything they do, but they do many things well. The atmosphere inside and on the back patio is very cool (love the tables with the couch seating) and the bar has a nice feel to it. The music can be pretty cheesy at times, but strangely enough it adds to the ambiance.  I love their bread, caesar salad and gnocchi, and the insalata caprese looked really good. I've had the gnocchi (at least) the last three times I've been here, and as a result I can't remember if I liked the other meals I've had here as much as the gnocchi.  During my most recent visit the staff was totally on top of everything, but I do remember experiencing spotty service at times in the past. Of course, since I hadn't been here in four years the staff from my last visit may have moved on...  This is a great place to go if you're looking to have a fun time with a group, and the food is quite affordable.

-kjqzgbWnoUteHiNnWJ51w.review_text: I was here a LONG time ago (maybe 10 years ago?) - it was late at night and I was with a bunch of hospitality people - we were very very very very not sober.  I remembered being enchanted with the little garden pathway and the pretty christmas lights on the back patio where we all chainsmoked through dinner - We just had a thoroughly delightful time there  So I just went back to check it out, to see what it really was like - and it sucked.    It was uber-terrible- there are these fake plaster rails that run through the space that I think are supposed to look like grapevines but they look like stiff dog doo - and the food is REALLY REALLY awful.    We must have been REALLY messed up when we were here.

EE_7_YPuk9Ly05hi1N-Lig.review_text: Nestled in a romantic little garden off Grant & Green, Bocce welcomes the diner with soft lighting, high ceilings, and a homespun Italian flair.  The menu is pretty balanced, though I always order the Gnocci Napolitana (potato dumplings in pink sauce) because I am quite fond of it.  Most entrees fall in the range of $8 to $13-- pretty reasonable for the nice setting.  I wouldn't say it's the greatest Italian place in North Beach, but it certainly provides a good dollars-to-romance (DTR) ratio.  And I should know: DTR optimization is lifelong hobby of mine.

suuIf6JWTZFjSu55k7zTBA.review_text: *4.5*  - An urban Oasis, tucked away in the heart of North Beach. - Outdoor patio with lots of elbow room. - Inside old stone lodge ambiance with high ceilings. - Live music on certain nights. - Great for groups. - Friendly service. - Pastas, pizzas, burger, sandwiches, lasagna, and a variety of appetizers. - Food delicious and very reasonably priced.  I've been here for lunch and dinner.  When I went for dinner, crowd was pretty lively.  Lunch was like our own private dining experience. Very Zen.

PKx2ppUjiedPv0mGcnKzrg.review_text: Good food and service. Will definitely suggest for friends.

HbXFXjIwTqYM7mM9bbqaNA.review_text: Bocce Cafe remains my favorite Italian Restaurant in North Beach and in the Bay Area for the that matter. I love the food, especially the chicken lasagna! Eating in the outdoor courtyard is very peaceful and relaxing while contrasting the busy North Beach streets outside. The place is a little quirky as you'll surely be greeted by the cat missing his tail but will gladly accept table scraps if it is a dish that he likes. The men's restroom is also quirky as one of the urinals is right in front of a window. Since finding parking on hilly streets in North Beach can be a nightmare, I recommend the Valet parking!

582iTyqKkoHeBFPMJuQEJw.review_text: Maaaaaaaaaaaaaannnnnn, people are way to critical.  Put a keyboard in front of someone with taste buds they feel that they can flame out anyone for a bad experience.  BTW I believe that bad experiences seem to follow people.  Many don't realize that they are the constant variable in all of the bad things that happen around them.  This place doesn't have the best service I'll admit.  Its food has always been better than average but not earth shattering.  The interior decor looks like a small version of Macaroni grill meets Olive Garden (read trying to look authentic) but it never detracts from your experience and it is slightly cozy with a super huge bar (Yes!  Booze!)  The patio is down right effin nice and always worth the wait.  So the skinny really is this: service=average, food=average+, ambiance=average+...that would make it a 3.5er...but there is something else that needs mentioning.  First, they are VERY accommodating for big parties.  I don't mean an 8 or a 10 top...I mean like 100+.  Second, they provide the canvas and its up to you to paint the picture. Allow me to explain.  Nothing of Bocce will detract from your experience.  Rather, it sets the table  (in a figurative sense) well, I guess literally too.  Bocce allows you to comfortably dine while enjoying the MOST important part..your friends and family.  Not once have I gone where anyone left unhappy.  It is always seems like there were no distractions so we can enjoy each other's company.  Its a safe bet...as long as you are not one of those people that bad things seem to always happen to.

XF8ALuBfoEfO8t3C88fugQ.review_text: Some of you Yelpers are harsh!  I have never had a bad meal here, and I think it's WAYYY better than a lot of the other N Beach Italian offerings..... I've been lots of times - in groups sizes varying from 2 to 20, and the service has always been adequate and the food great.    I really like their mussels appetizer (served in a big iron pot, and LOVE to dip bread in the yummy broth), and their chicken marsala.  Of course the food is not stellar - and it's not trying to be - just consistently good traditional dishes.... and the ambience, esp. the patio on a nice day, is great!  I take my parents here every time they visit - they are from a small town and are not fans of fancy, pretentious food - so they love it here!    On a particularly memorable visit here, a friend and I teamed up against another two friends to see who could be first to finish the "Meal for 2" - basically a sampler platter with all diff types of pasta.  This was NOT a good idea..... they should call this the meal for 3 or 4 - it is huge.  And we had already had lots of appetizers, not to mention the 10 or so cocktails we had at happy hour before this.  Anyhow, it was a brave attempt, but, sadly, both teams ended up forfeiting.  Good thing it was already midnight when we finished dinner with 20+ people - we were too stuffed to make much effort at going out afterwards.  Alas, we all headed home with our leftovers.  It was a good night all around.... :)

OX2rtyuYxbf9pB-nRr2IRQ.review_text: Came here with 3 other people.  It was quiet, not crowded and a great place to relax for a Sunday evening dinner. Service was great.  Grilled salmon gave what I thought was a pretty generous portion for the money.  Meatballs were super tender and delicious.

E4SUAOb7-ayDnKN-lFQf8w.review_text: Great find, away from the tourist crowd.  Thanks to my friend Steve for finding the place

z5VGf197EBrPyqKYtlmP1w.review_text: LOVE...LOVE...LOVE this Italian restaurant. I really do. The food is tasty the price is so right and they even have jazz players perform there on Friday and I believe Saturday. They even have a fantastic outside seating. When its a nice warm night you can sit outside even when is nice and cold you can choose to sit outside because they have heating lamps.   Even the indoor seating is so comfy. This place, in my opinion is great for a first time date.....

hC5DNm-_znN5DyQ2LyB7Lw.review_text: I had my graduation dinner here and they took all 16 of us with no problem!   They definitely know how to take care of groups. The owner approached me, after chatting with my parents and congratulated me on my graduation. The staff was friendly and patient for us to order and brought out all the food at the same time. The corkage fee was only $12 a bottle and we were able to bring our own desert without a fee (but we didn't- and their deserts were incredible). Also, they had a live band playing jazz music in the corner!   Their appetizers were incredible! mmm I can just taste the fresh buchetta now! My meal was not the most amazing, but my friend who ordered a fettucini pasta dish was great!   If you need a nice, not too fancy, not too cheap looking kinda place for a large group last minute this is the place to come!

Fuo3Zlw9a2AIBTLru7RunQ.review_text: I have been going to that place for over 10 years and love it.  Keep going back.  The staff is very nice and service couldn't be better.  This is a real gem where tourists can't easily find that place.  More for local people.  Live Jazz band late night makes is really romantic and precious atmosphere. Good job guys!!

erUUJU_w5j_pmQPAdZBzbg.review_text: This place is great. Been coming here for years. There is outdoor seating and live music. The manicotti was excellent and I had a very smooth chianti classico. This place is a solid recommend.

iUeZhkI0OK0BisakOkb3pQ.review_text: I'm with the basic, good, cheap Italian votes. It was four-stars back in the dark ages when they had an actually bocce court in the back.

g3suHxtH49EZc5McdMhInQ.review_text: I ate at Bocce for the first time last week with my Eating San Francisco class. There were about 17 of us and they were able to accommodate us all in one large table fairly easily. It's very spacious and it's great for big groups.  The food itself is superb. I shared the pasta tricolor with a friend for less than $22. It's made of gnocchi in marinara, fettuccine alfredo and ravioli in pesto. Delicious!  The service was also great. The staff was very attentive and they even let us photograph and interview them for our class projects.  It's the perfect place for a night out with friends!

eUmVXP9UnoWtz9NSBwY4jA.review_text: If you like the food at Stinking Rose or Buca di Beppo you'll love the food at Bocce.  The only redeeming qualities of this place are the outdoor patio and the fact that you can usually get a table, even on weekends (gee, I wonder why?)

Sz600UsLJJaw9XDBpa_4ZQ.review_text: I've walked by this café countless times, and never really noticed it, assuming another old school hole-in-the-wall north beach Italian joint.  But, I finally rounded a group to give it a try.  And WHAT A SURPRISE!  When we walked in, I was totally shocked to find a nicer, fun environment in a huge space, with live band & even cute lighted courtyard out back!  We were seated in the outdoor courtyard, so I wasn't able to enjoy the music, however the outdoor atmosphere was still very fun.   Food, was just so-so.  But pretty cheap at ~$10 per plate for most pastas on the menu.  Overall, I definitely plan to be back.  Cheap food, good atmosphere, close-by, this will do!

YoC8_a-CvBGa4wcu0KRmXw.review_text: Wonderful food, very good service.  Would definitely go back again.

cVgV_aXaTGhUqBVwhVGtag.review_text: 2.5 stars.  This place reminds me of a mediocre tourist trap restaurant in Italy.  Everything - food, service, ambiance - is average bordering on below average.  Decor is cheesy and dated.  The upside:  they can accomodate larger groups, there is valet parking ($8), and the prices are really reasonable.

h_Cn2H6l7U7wtM_WDli8vA.review_text: good food, good ambiance. gets a bit too crowded and noisy. but i love that it's hidden from the street.

si6PQvWkseeWCcz16BmWCg.review_text: This place was pretty amazing many years ago.  It was a must go to when in North Beach on a date or with family.  Last couple of times I just was not impressed.  There was one large party that was getting all of the attention from the waiters and probably the kitchen too.  What they received we didn't.   So since it is a no reservation first come first serve type place take a look and see if there are any large parties on a week night.  The decor is nice but I enjoyed how it used to be,  The bar is pretty nice and the music is always good.  Like someone else said keep it simple and you'll be happy.  They accommodated a vegetarian friend very well.  The steak is not the greatest and presentation on the main dishes really kinda, well, sucked.  I will go back, maybe for lunch to try a pizza or pasta and see if  they can win me back.  Outside is nice, great wines, spotty service, great cheese and anti pasta.

vQvfR5H5ZRQNVgjLoqch-w.review_text: We went with some friends who were visiting for the weekend. The only thing that saved this place was a half decent calzone. The service was not great- slow and dull. cannelloni was awful- flavorless dog food. Do yourself a favor and skip this joint! I'm pretty sure neither the owners or chefs are Italian and it showed in the food!

XbxaaX2uwi84gcVoXSnPKA.review_text: The food here was ok not great, BUT the atmosphere and discreet location made it worthwhile. You won't have bums heckling you or tourists bumping into your tables. When I came here, we had the outside patio to ourselves and the neighbor's tabby cat at our feet. Our server of the night seemed to be in "high" spirits which made for some laughs. This place is a great spot for a mellow evening where company matters more than the food.

IpNBCDVMDm22-PI4KY_TUQ.review_text: GREAT FOR GROUPS!  8 of us were out celebrating a friend's birthday and we decided to have dinner and see a comedy show in North Beach.  Our group of 8 was seated right away, it was a Thursday night, so I don't know if Fri. & Sat. nights would be more difficult.  SERVICE: Emily was our server, she was pleasant & patient with a table full of testosterone. Drink order was efficient.  Appetizers came quickly.  Food orders accurate.  She understood we needed to attend a show (time) and was on top of it all night.  FOOD: Whenever I go to an Italian restaurante I order the Bruschetta, I was disappointed, flavor was very lacking...canned tomatoes? definitely not picked ripe from the vine.  Pizzas were good.  The meat lasagna was okay, nothing special.  Salmon not a strength (but why order this at an Italian place, we gave our buddy a ribbing about this).  BOTTOMLINE: In my opinion, there are plenty of great Italian restaurant in North beach, Bocce doesn't qualify in this respect.  I would recommend Bocce for group gatherings.  Singing happy birthday on a delivered, complementary chocolate cake slice was a highlight.

rfItQaeV_9vhvpGs5fhZvQ.review_text: Really enjoyed Bocce Cafe with friends visiting from LA/Ventura!  The reviews were only 3.5 so we were skeptical but the other places we considered were full and this place had valet parking- very convenient when parking was otherwise difficult to find.   The pizza and soup and salad were all very tasty. Service was good. The live music was an unexpected surprise. It added to the ambiance while Not being so loud that it was overbearing. I recommend it and would go again.

ffVswRme8oPvgiLpGxW5NQ.review_text: This place is great. The decor may seem a bit odd, especially when compared to other Italian restaurants in the area, but the ambiance and cuisine are authentic to northern Italy which is unique for this area. It's a great spot for most occasions and the food is excellent.

RgotWt-6_53vAkQfIc81Dw.review_text: Bocce is the perfect place for a large party. After making a reservation for 14 on Opentable.com, my friends and I dined here for our pre-race dinner before the San Francisco Marathon. The menu is extensive and includes all the usual Italian favorites. And the prices can't be beat. I shared the calamari appetizer with friends. It was very mediocre and was served with what tasted like bottled cocktail sauce. The mixed green salad was good, as was the capellini with fresh tomato sauce. Nothing really stood out, but nothing was bad either. I think my favorite part of the meal was the bread basket. I don't know if they make their own bread, but the assorted varieties were delicious. I wouldn't go out of my way to eat at Bocce, but it was perfect for the occasion. It looked like there were mostly big groups there the night we came, including a birthday party. It's not every restaurant that can accommodate several large groups at the same time, but Bocce sure can.

E1Il-RLY8dmPeR8e_ZSekA.review_text: Very cool walkway in. I love feeling like you are "discovering" a new place by entering an ostensibly tiny little place only to find that you are walking into a lush garden and finding your way into a gorgeous and huge restaurant.   Great for groups with lots of space.   American-Italian, which means that there's all the standard things you would find at a restaurant in the midwest serving up mediocre Italian.   I got the pomodoro, which was pretty good, but I got to taste everyone else's at the table and felt bad for them. Pizza was meh, veal parm tasted like chicken fried steak with tomato sauce.   Don't think we'll be going back. Such a shame that a cool space has blah food.

c1TZj4ycuImrQoXTNE948w.review_text: Love this restaurant! Great location, valet parking, great for a date. The portions are pretty big, prices are reasonable. The environment is romantic, and the outside seating area is big, and on a warm night out it's perfect. Great for big groups and the staff is really nice. I think you can also make reservations on Opentable.com

-Gc-c7pzR1GK9JRVNV-4WQ.review_text: It's all about the patio! Well, no, they also have music and nice service and a fun atmosphere. But one afternoon I stopped by for a late lunch, around 2:00, and sat with just a few other people on the patio. Fantastic! A little wine, a little sun, a little shade, a little wind through the fig tree overhead, a little stray cat passing by now and then...a little slice of heaven. And not too pricey!

NN5jldDW0Puf8E3ZZjKqsg.review_text: A wierd place - it looks kinda fancy when you walk in, with it's high ceilings, terraced dining room and full bar. But when you sit down you realize that everyone in the place is decidedly un-fancy, and they have really large portions at really reasonable prices. The service can be slow, but is always friendly.

0hxJIpTjywflPy4qTC51Ww.review_text: I went here for the first time last weekend--Friday night.  First off, you walk through a garden-esque type walkway to enter the restaurant, which is very cute.  Once inside, the decor is very different, but in a good way.  Quite a large place, but it still feels homey.    The food is delicious!  I went with 3 of my friends who all enjoyed their meals as well.  Also, they have a full-bar, which is a plus!  The prices are super cheap...but thankfully that does not compromise the food one bit!    Only negative--I made reservations that day around noon, but once we got there, they did not have my reservation:(  Luckily the hostess was very nice and put us at the top of the waiting list.    I would definitely go back!  A nice change from the same ol' Italian restaurant!

WQdXrs4QZWCeFsSBhUdosg.review_text: nice italian restaurant in touristy NorthBeach, a few blocks off of Columbus, so you can actually be among people from your city.  Spacious, good food, affordable, unpretencious, nice outdoor area (granted the heater do all the work). I like Bocce because it's different than the rest out there in NB. Cheesy live band.

2sMKa3EjmKP7OoPI_6GUzw.review_text: Great food and I love the live music :)

d_Bg88z72HQXt89MnSQ33g.review_text: Typical Southern Italian food.  the pasta's are tasty and the price is right.  nothing too exciting though so I don't know if I'd seek them out again...although that Caesar salad was excellent.  I like the stone benches but the wall art creeps me out.

KVShxUV_XFuoF30ttAeoNw.review_text: This is a real hidden gem in SF. Great atmosphere food and reasonable prices. I had the gnocchi which was super homemade light and soft like a pillow. They have valet parking at $10 the near by garage is about $9. I will be back.

ZGiXcOTc508cAer5aZlQqg.review_text: the food is tasteless.  i like the decor of the restaurant tho.  its so quaint.

oniIxWz5eKtDfG53RsLBpQ.review_text: After a great day of walking around town, our cab driver drove us by this place and told us to eat there.  The decor is not very fiting, but the food was excellent.  I had a massive calzone that that did not disappoint.    it was nice to find a casual place that did not break the bank for lunch like the rest of San Francisco.  It is worth the trip.

cqGzzeRwKvTamliSZPM95w.review_text: I could have eaten the plate and had a better culinary experience.  I had a  Margherita pizza at Bocce Cafe. It was the most flat and uninspired pizza I had ever tasted. It really tasted like a bad -really bad mind you -  frozen pizza.  Honestly, I could have had a Digiorno's.  The environment is nice, but the ambiance can't make up for the lame pizza. Grant it, I haven't tried other items on the menu, but if the pizza is that bad I don't want to know about the rest. There are so many other places in Little Italy with better pizza. Cross this one off your list.

XZ7gWj4cIbFJOhG03lYY7w.review_text: I used to consider this place the best place in North Beach, some years ago. Since then I've discovered many other places, so I figured Bocce was old hat. Admittedly I was trying to go back to Tony's new Pizza Nepolitana, but I was disappointed to find that they are closed on Mondays and Tuesdays, so we walked around looking for a place to dine and I remembered Bocce. Glad I did. The atmosphere is fun. It's kind of like an old barn or warehouse or something. They didn't have a jazz duo on Monday, but I remember that when those guys play it is a good touch. We were both very impressed with the food. We started with bruschetta and caprese. We both agreed the bruschetta was excellent; not too heavy or full of garlic, fresh tomatoes and the bread was good too. The caprese was good, not the best ever, but good enough. The warm bread they served with olive oil and vinegar was very tasty and fresh. My date loved her pasta. She's not always easy to please in the pasta department, so I was thrilled that she enjoyed it.  I had the chicken picatta for an entree. I think this is what I ordered so many times in the past (funny how we stick with what we know). I was very pleasantly surprised to see that I really did know good food even back then. This dish is fantastic! It was served steaming hot, a huge bonus in my book, as many fine restaurants I've been to have brought their main courses out lukewarm..I really hate it when that happens. Not here. The picatta sauce was a perfect blend of lemony, buttery, creamy zest loaded with capers. The chicken was excellent quality, the steamed veggies as a side were perfectly cooked and seasoned (not overly seasoned) and the pasta as the other accompanying side was satisfying. All this and cheap wine to boot! We got a bottle of Hess Chardonnay for $24 (or maybe it was $32, can't remember, but Hess is good Chardonnay and that was an excellent price).  The service was decent. At one point I asked if I could have my chardonnay chilled, to which our waitress responded "isn't it cold enough? More ice won't make any difference." I decided to let it go, realizing it isn't a 5 star restaurant, and it was served adequately cold, but I could have done without that. Still, I see some peoples' complaints that seem so menial and baseless, so I have to say here that overall it was a very enjoyable experience, I'm glad I rediscovered it, and I will definitely keep in mind for future North Beach endeavors.

WGN8Ss7cEMInobRC3B5t6Q.review_text: Nice ambiance. Prices were decent and food quality was pretty good. There is really nothing unique about the menu as for specialty dishes. Just your typical Italian dishes.

_zTPktfP5SX_fdduew6lCw.review_text: My daughter ordered a cheeseburger,I wish I had also, in fact, everyone in our group wished the same thing. I took two bites and pushed my plate away. The wine could have come out of a box and the beer I ordered from the tap had absolutely no head on it. No wonder I was able to get in without a wait. Avoid this place like the plague

56NWgfYChWGSPpxcSW19jA.review_text: One of my favorite places to eat Italian food because they have pretty good food and their prices aren't that high. They have a great atmosphere for a get together with friends also. The live music help but sometimes the music gets annoying. But overall, their service and food are great, definitely this place.

Y2iLLq02CUVfKHsowQ4wXw.review_text: OK let's be honest. We're not coming here because of the extraordinary Italian food. But we are coming here because their patio is awesome and they can handle a group of 30 like champs. Oh, and they have valet parking right in front.

o8olAqhfBpruVoHZE4bcuQ.review_text: This is a good place to go if you have a large group and everyone is emphazing that they do not want to pay too much for dinner. It can't be a franchise place like Olive Garden and it also must have atmosphere. This place, the Bocce Cafe fits the bill so nicely.   Hidden away in a garden alley in North Beach was this fine restaurant with tables and couch chairs. The rooms are very ornate with lots of chandeliers. There was also an outdoor patio,  but it was too cold and dark to sit outside. I had a delicious salmon fetticine with a cream sauce (lol, everytime I write these restaurant reviews, I never know what I ate, only what I saw and tasted).   Our table is near a band with an Italian singer, which is kind of too close, but we didn't care. Also, I recommend this place if you want to go on a date. You feel like you are on vacation someplace, somewhere in Italy! If you have a choice and You want atmosphere, don't go to Pasta Pomodoro or the Olive Garden.

YFOc0FaGBN5ujuuyjbw6Wg.review_text: The food, atmosphere and service at Bocce was excellent. I don't know if there's a better value for your money in all of North Beach, at least for Italian food. There are ample vegetarian options and the outdoor seating is quaint and romantic. Highly recommended.

uz4Mth028has4iB0r7a8Dw.review_text: Sodini's had a one and a half hour wait so i went to this place and they seated us right away. That should have been a warning. I'm pretty sure they bought the pizza and cannelloni at somewhere less fancy than Costco, there's no way you could make fresh food taste so mass produced. The live music was so atrocious it could have been an old Will Ferrel skit. The service was mediocre with drinks taking ages to arrive - it doesn't take 20 minutes to mix 2 bottles of moretti and a glass of supermarket Chianti. Dire, absolutely dire.

ogC3E1GY-IIyOf_kSbz6TA.review_text: Probably not gonna come back here again for the reasons listed below:   1.  Hostess really wasn't in to being a hostess - I think.    2.  Seating went from crappy (pretty much sat at the hostess's booth) to crappier (sharing a bench with the "make out kings").    3.  Survey by the "make out kings" on whether we liked to do laundry cuz "she" did, followed by giggles and more smooching  (for the record I do not like to do laundry).   4.  No service for the first 20 + minutes    5. Chewy ravioli  6. Broken top to the olive oil holder thingy that resulted in a plate full of olive oil  7.  They only give you two pieces of the garlic bread.  The rest is plain.  I would probably go back for these reasons:   1.   The bread ... mmmmm.  The Garlic bread one is the best of the basket.    2. The live music   Pretty interesting night!

5cd9IdAV9Dce3BdRDh9qCQ.review_text: my roomie had her birthday party here on the outdoor patio, and i must say that the atmosphere was fantastic, albeit a bit too romantic for dinner with 25 of her closest family members, but thats besides the point. i enjoyed the food... the mussels were awesome, but i had little love for the service. 40 minutes to get a iced tea refill? meh. oh well, i think the guy was just bitter that there was a gagillion of us and only three waiters rotating on our party.

kMYUzzg-jm2T-eKg5N3p8g.review_text: Color me dissapointed with the food, I did appreciate the heavy handed poor for my drink.

qzDsm_hKogII5g3qM9XilA.review_text: This place is awesome!  I love the secret walkway entrance!!  The food is outstanding and there's groovy live music in the evenings. Eat here!

O-uPZruoYgNhY__yq03jmg.review_text: Soulful Italian Comfort Food Here!  I came here with five other college buddies and strolled around North Beach until our 8:30pm reservations. Convenient valet parking was available if you didn't want to look for your own parking or pay to park your car in a lot. There was a large green awning covering a narrow walkway leading to a side door entrance. The place is bigger than what is perceived outside. While we waited, there was a live band playing jazz. The dining room layout was very spacious with a bar, fireplace, outside patio, and plenty of group and couples seating. The restaurant had a warm rustic old-world charm to it with Mediterranean style colored walls and tiles to match. Italian decorations made the area feel more lively and festive. The crowds were so rambunctious and loud, I found myself screaming to speak to one of our guys across my table.   The menu had a lot of selections ranging from Antipasti to Secondi dishes. I heard from one of the guys who reserved this restaurant, all dishes are huge for the amount of money you pay. Although we each ordered our own dishes, we were open to share family style as well. This is what our group ordered: 1 Antipasto Della Casa (great assortment of a couple pieces of each appetizer item on the menu) 1 Bruschetta (3 slices of toasted bread topped off with chunks of tomato, garlic, and basil) 1 Fried Calamari (golden brown fried calamari with red marinara and a chunky tartar sauce) 1 Large Ceasar Salad (shared among two) 1 Small Ceasar Salad (chopped crisp romaine lettuce tossed with a strong and flavorful anchovy and Caesar salad dressing garnished with croutons and thinly sliced parmigiano) 1 Gnocchi (A plate full of chewy potato dumplings with a creamy pesto sauce. Very delicate and yummy!) 1 Linguini with Fresh Mussels (great presentation with lots of linguini tossed with a deep red spicy marinara sauce and topped off with at least a half dozen steamed mussels) 1 Fish of the Day: Swordfish (didn't get to try it, but the presentation looked hearty and delicious with a cream sauce and vegetables) 3 Ciopinnos (This was the most expensive dish in the restaurant at $21.95 each, but well worth it! It was two-fold; one pot full of Crab, prawns, salmon, calamari, clams & mussels in a hearty Marinara sauce soup similar looking to a Minestrone soup served with a heaping serving of pasta with marinara sauce on the side. Delicious and Very Filling. The seafood made the savory broth taste amazing and chunks of vegetables were superb.)  I hope you could tell my main dish was Ciopinno and my appetizer was sharing a large Caesar salad. Because the Ciopinno was a large order in itself, it took longer to completely devour than other plates. I found myself halfway done while the other 3 were finished with their plates. The hearty stock and soup was contained in a stove pot and marinara pasta in another plate. I did get to taste each of the plates except for the Swordfish. Everything looked picture worthy but I failed to take pictures because I was hungry along with the rest of my party. After we finished each of our plates, we were full enough not to order dessert. When the bill arrived, with tip, each person gave $37. I think a good hearty meal coupled with lifelong friends is well worth the money paid. I figured, if I had as much fun and enjoyment eating here, I know everyone else would too!  Bellissimo!

_bF7I69OrJtLQPTsWZMNqQ.review_text: This place topped my graduation day!! I chose this place after readings tons of reviews on Italian restaurants in the city. I was hoping that to find a place that would be a comfortable setting for family as well as a child.   Came here this past Friday mid-afternoon after making reservations.  Here are the highlights:  Great Service: Walking in we were greeted and led to the back heated glass patio for our table. I loved this because we felt like we were sectioned off to have our own private dinner and it felt so VIP yet welcoming. Our server was very friendly and did not ever rush or constantly over ask about the service.  The restaurant inside is beautiful as well. It has this home feeling to it. The lighting with the decor is very traditional family style. I can see friends and family equally enjoying time here.  The food: Delicious!!! Everything had a great taste, from the Fried Calamari to the Spaghetti, nothing was off in taste. Plus, the portions were pretty giving.   Thanks Bocce!! I will be back!!

4hN_0-9l0gffb5rOu6OAtA.review_text: Great, solid food at reasonable prices  The chairs are extremely comfortable.  Walking in here is like escaping from North Beach into another world.  I got the sausage sandwich at lunch--it was a great value and very filling, and cost less than $7.

VEGuRegmzThcBbnV3GGGFg.review_text: Ate here with my friends prior to the NWM! I was thinking I would be carb-loading before the marathon but I saw cioppino on the menu and knew that's what I wanted. It came with a side of pasta which was a plus! When my meal came I was surprised how huge the bowl was! There was so much seafood in that bowl, I was totally full and content. The atmosphere was cozy, we had a table next to a cushioned bench and I enjoyed the dimness of the restaurant.

5FmzKy16w9feXeRwMqEX4Q.review_text: I've been here several times over the years.  The quality is not thrilling, but it's one of the better places I've found to take out-of-town guests who insist on a "traditional" Italian meal in North Beach.  It works well for big groups (even with kids) and I've never felt crowded there.

-Ox9xMII04O381mFX-JSBw.review_text: I like the Kurdish people working there, they are very friendly and nice.  And their food is definitely better than the average of Little Italy - I like to go there when nobody is around during weekdays.  And I have to mention the price - if you are sick of average pasta with high price in Little Italy, it's worth walking a bit farther (just a bit) and get lost in their small "woods" of Bocce Cafe...  If your wallet is crying, then you can go have some of their specials (I think it was like 6 bucks!!!)

eurIEcpGa_tTi1LMWa1pUA.review_text: I was going to give Bocce Cafe 3 stars, but they kind of dropped the ball at the end of our meal, so they got demoted to 2 star status. Here's the low down:  The girl lives on the other side of Columbus, up the hill in "Chinatown Heights" and we were looking for something not too far away, with outdoor seating. Yelp told us that this place might be hit or miss, but we decided that's half the fun. So away we went.  The location of Bocce is pretty keen. The little alley way that opens up to the lodge-like main space is fun and cute. Speaking of that main space, it's pretty neat. I don't know how well it functions as an Italian restaurant, it seems more suited to a martini bar or perhaps ski lodge, but it's funky and different.  The hostess warned us against seating in the patio as it was windy. Fair enough, we'll take a couch seat in the corner, then. The food was not at all impressive, but the Special (pick from 4 pastas and a variety of sauces) was decent for the price. Calamari wasn't so great. As an indication to portion and food quality, I had left overs from my Fettuccine Alfredo that I didn't really feel were worth taking home. That's pretty rare for me to leave a man behind like that.  So they collected our plates and offered us a dessert menu that was quite slow in arriving. Then it took them forever to come and take our dessert order. To top that whole ordeal off, I ordered a Grappa and what I was served was gross. Awful.  If you want some food, come here, but it's nothing special. I think Midwesterners visiting SF may really enjoy it (there was a party of such having a grand ol' time the night we were there), and it can certainly handle a large group with no problems.

uLQeiEXcCwt8cRBwpBM-qQ.review_text: I'm a bit taken back by Bocce's 3 and a half star average rating. I found myself really dissapointed here. My fiance and I approached this place anticipating something other than what we found. I think the sight of valet guys out front sort of indicated that this would be a place people would want to come too. Its locale in north beach indicated to me it would uphold the standard of authenticity that is the driving force behind many north beach eateries. The walk up to the front door, down a dark but clean alley caused my spidey senses to tingle. I knew this would either be the begining of a really great, intimate dining experience or it would simply be the begining of the end.   We walked into the front door and we were caught off gaurd by the Gypsy Kings playing over the house system. All of a sudden I'm not sure if I have a hankering for tapas or tortellini. The room was big and cold. Oh, and practically empty. It had all the makings of a great Colorado ski lodge. It had none of the makings of a great Italian dining establishment as far as I can tell. I was ready to split. My fiance encouraged me to give it a shot, if for no other reason than not appearing rude. I agreed.   She, like a pro, ordered caprese salad and prosciutto and melon. It was kind of hott, seeing her so decisive and cultured and shtuff. I think it was pretty clear to the server that we would be ordering meals after the appetizer, as evidenced by the fact we held onto our menus after ordering apps. First the bread came out. And it was good. Then the caprese salad and prosciutto y melon arrived. The salad was a terrible. The cheese was soggy. It certainly didnt taste fresh and they used the wrong tomatoes. The melon was killer. This was the only saving grace for the whole experience. It made me happy. Like "giddy" happy. Now, in fairness prosciutto and melon is pretty hard to screw up. What does it say about a place that their only saving grace is a dish thats impossible to screw up, and fairly easy to gather ingredients for? Exactly, i think you get my drift.   Well, there we were eating our apps, menus on the table. The server never came back to see about the remainder of our order. It's just as well as at this point we were not considering ordering anything else. After our apps we waited. And waited. FInally I had to find our waiter and ask for him to bring our bill, which he had not yet prepared. We paid about 19 bucks before tip. I wouldnt consider it a total waste. For 19 bucks i learned a valuable lesson. It goes like this "The next time I'm greeted by the Gypsy Kings at an eating establishment I'd better be ordering tapas or paella". Lesson learned.

SmvJgnv7SjGrvS2N-xiR-A.review_text: great place for large groups (our group was around 30) and really nice spacious ambiance.  there is available patio seating for sunny days. i was really pleased with the salmon pasta dish and the pizza we ordered.

ve1mwGT0e8j-GSWrzF0Lbw.review_text: All in all a excellent night. Have come here for many years and the food is just getting better and better. Service is very good too. Place is good for larger groups.

33jCqhxYeHPoC3wQBQ23DA.review_text: This place reminded me of every single reason why I despise Italian food.    We were there in a large group, probably around 30 people split between 2 tables.  They had a set meal for the group, and we had a choice of 3 entrees: lasagna, swordfish, or chicken parmigiana.  I chose the chicken parmigiana, and when it finally got to me, I felt like I went back in time... back to when I was living in my college dorm, and I had just sat down in the cafeteria with my place of chicken parmigiana that the angry and bitter cafeteria worker slopped on my plate.  It was terrible.  Like I said, everything I despise about Italian food.  It was lukewarm, the taste was so incredibly generic, the chicken was dry... ugh.  Right now as I write this review, my belly is basking in the afterglow of a $5 Shake-and-Bake meal that I cooked myself.  It is roughly 850x better and more tasty than the garbage that I was forced to eat at Bocce Cafe.  Maybe if you go for an individual meal, it might be better... I dunno.  I won't ever find out because if I'm in North Beach, there are plenty of other restaurants for me to try before I ever darken their doorstep again.    But absolutely avoid it if you want to go for a party, or in a large group.  You will pay premium prices for dorm food.

L7hsXiRm9La5Jx8tuMUJCw.review_text: I have gone back and forth on whether I should post this and have decided to post: our dining experience at the Bocce Cafe last night was abysmal. Cold food, we had to send Melanie's soup back, wretched and in attentive service, inexplicably long wait (over an hour and the place wasn't even busy), and lousy food. Also, I tried to find the manager but no one could tell me where the manager was last night. No stars. We salvaged the evening by going to Caffe Grecco for dessert. Perhaps The Bocce Cafe is better than this but I will never find out because we are never going back.

Glt6xvnJVXg5n6rtWF_-4w.review_text: Hidden in the back of a building but our friends heard good things about this restaurant in North Beach. So we went.  The ambience is beautiful but honestly the the food was mediocre for the price.   There are other good Italian restaurants around.

MJ6I2dX9-QZMw5bL-9inTA.review_text: It's good to have friends with great taste! They bring you to great little restaurants like Bocce Café! A nice delightful dinner with a live band to lighten up the mood.

uBTXj8n5tyWpBPKCBgYTqw.review_text: What a disappointment; in both food and service.  We visited on a Wednesday for a late lunch (party of 5).  There was only one other table occupied in this large restaurant but they still seated us up front by the hostess station.  Strike One.  I ordered a house salad with balsamic vinegrette and bruschetta.The greens were old and the salad was swimming in dressing.    The oil in the dressing tasted rancid, the balsamic was so bitter and disgusting I'm sure it wasn't real balsamic.  The bruschetta was so forgettable - boring bread with the consistancy of stale white bread oven "toasted" the day before.  The tomatoes were underripe and had no flavor and the shaved piece of "Parmesan" tasted like plastic.  My sister ordered the ravioli in meat sauce.  The flavor was okay but not great.  However it would have been much better if the raviolis weren't swimming in a pool of grease.  Strike two!  Lastly, the service was bad.  We had to ask for everything, including water refills which should be automatic.  You would think that only having one table to attend the waiter would have paid a little more attention.  Strike Three and you're out!

-KwI_4TXVh3armDASq1pCg.review_text: Many vegetarian options, live jazz, little anyone wants to eat.   We chose Bocce after seeing BBB, because who doesn't like Italian? We had a very large party (16+) people and Bocce was willing to accomodate us all at 9PM. They had several vegetarian options including soup in a veggie broth, which satisfied friends usually stuck with a salad at most other restaurants.    The jazz was incredibly fun and we had plenty of space to stretch out.  But either the chef had gone home early, or was in the home stretch because the food was just deplorable. The gnocchi was pasty, not tasty, the meatballs...Mama Mia who does not make good meatballs at an Italian restaurant, the meatballs sat on our plates barely touched.  I had the rib eye demiglacce which seemed to be code for, bathed in sugar so I wouldn't tell what a fatty mess it was. I almost stole the tofu lasagna off my friend's plate, but it was also sitting there, half-touched.  Judging by other reviews we seemed to have caught them on a bad night, but my personal experience says not to go back.

of-Kuw-FAB59_b5YlUtGSQ.review_text: I came here for a friend's birthday with a party of 8.  I liked the ambiance and design of the place  - very different than other places in SF.  We had calamari and bruschetta to start. The calamari was just okay but I really enjoyed the bruschetta.  We had caesar salad before dinner came and it was very good.  I chose a spicy seafood pasta and was pleasantly surprised.  The seafood was good and the sauce was delicious.  The live music was a nice treat and they even sang Happy Birthday to my friend.  We had a couple of desserts to share and had a great time.  I would definitely recommend it for large groups.

fqIWhF0pL2TI4VHsM7rOLg.review_text: This restaurant is a surprise when you discover it. It's tucked back from the street, on a small plant lined walkway between two buildings. The restaurant has high ceiling and ornate vine-like railings throughout. Nice bar and patio seating. Good food and prices making it great for large groups. Good wine list. Valet parking available. Friendly atmosphere. Live music on some nights, call for details...415-981-2044.

ra3OzaxpILytSjHRRKoT8g.review_text: It's cheap, the atmosphere is fine, and so it's that place for the cheap group lunch.

tYtb1BaCemElycZqOvG37A.review_text: My friend and I stumbled upon Bocce Cafe while looking for a place to eat. Walking down the tree-lined lane to the restaurant entrance was just the start of a very nice meal.  I had the ravioli with a very nice meat sauce. Not runny, not dry. Very tasty! My friend had the tortellini and was also very pleased. I definitely feel like I "got my moneys worth". Low-ish prices, but quality food.  The service was very attentive (we were there for an "early" dinner, about 7) and non-forceful. They let us eat without interruption and were nearby if we needed anything. Oh! And our food came quickly! Neither of us could believe how fast it came out.  If we didn't already have plans, we would've stayed for the night! Comfy chairs and tables and the jazz trio was wonderful.

ruqWvBAPf7Crqln4xu7xmw.review_text: This was my second time at this restaurant, and some things were consistent, while others failed miserably.  Service was spotty, due to it being packed and on a Saturday night.  The noise level was high, which made it difficult to hear and understand our waiter (speaking a dialect that I did not recognize).  He sounded like father Guido sarducci from Saturday Nigh Live of years ago.  The antipasti was nice - similar to last time, but not as fresh as it could have been.  It must have been a bitch to open those containers and plate the food....  The special this evening was a tri plate of chicken, sausage and beef with smashed potatoes and 'veggies'.  I had to look very hard to find those veggies.  What I thought I was going to get vs what I got was night and day.  If they sliced the chicken breast, sausage and london broil any thinner,  you would be able to read through it.  I bet the 1 chicken breast, sausage and london broil used on this dish served 20 people.  Honestly - it was that bad.  Keep it simple, and you should be fine.  Simple pasta dishes that the Mexican kitchen staff can cook in this Italian restaurant would be best.

0Cvgx6MKrSOTUxGoUpdaTg.review_text: Been here twice..very accomodating for a large party as I had my bday dinner here.  The calamari and mussel appetizer is a must.  Although I do not like lasagna much it was really not bad.  I went there when they has filet mignon as the special melted in my mouth.

puS8HuNdeXhhl5F4bb0EEg.review_text: The main entrance is off to the side of the restaurant.  Upon entering,  I liked how the place felt.  It was okay.  We went here for a wedding rehearsal dinner.  We were given the outdoor patio dining area and I was happy they had heaters.   At least where I was sitted, the heater was behind me.   But it wasn't long that I start feeling the cold  The setting wasn't consistent and the heater was blowing cold air.  At one time, we had to cover it until it was blowing hot air again.  I don't like feeling cold and that made me a little unhappy.  I ordered the Rib Eye Steak (Demiglace, mushrooms and red wine sauce with pasta and vegetables).  Nothing wow, it was okay.  My friend got the Linguini Pescatore (Clams, mussels, calamari, prawns & salmon in a Marinara sauce) and it was enjoyed.  Service was great.  We didn't have to wait a long time for our dishes.  The one thing I liked also was the bottle of Cab they served.  I'm a big fan of Cabs so I was happy with the wine selection for our table.  I'm very particular with bathrooms and I was disappointed with theirs.  It was a step down to what the restaurant's feel was.  It was clean but small,  they could have done better.  I was using the full size mirror when I nearly tripped because of the slopey hill pavement, they could have at least made the flooring even.     Well, inspite of that, I could definitely dine here again and check out the bar and other menu items.

pUopzKhcjsOALWhE2nbKbA.review_text: Pretty mediocre Italian food. It's not too expensive, but it's also not too good...I think Olive Garden might be better.  The wine list is pretty limited, but they have a big bar. The spaghetti and meatballs were unremarkable and sort of soggy. The pasta with vodka sauce and salmon was good, and the house salad had yummy dressing.   I did like aspects of the restaurant, like the comfy couch banquets, but there was a lot of kitsch Italian stuff on the walls, and the space is a bit unfinished feeling and not very intimate.  It seems like a good place to go with a big group, and we had no problem walking in, but that convenience is offset by the parking situation in the neighborhood, which is difficult. They do offer valet.

t2q90BpipbvUco5SNgXb9A.review_text: We were first-timers at Bocce Cafe last night and were pleasantly surprised - by everything! Prices were excellent, interior was pretty and comfortable, service was friendly and attentive, and the food was great! We ordered a small caesar salad and a pasta dish, shared both, and were stuffed. Unlike some other restaurants on this warm SF weeknight, they were not crowded - quite the opposite. They have a large garden patio well protected from the elements, a full bar, and a varied menu. Just a short way up the hill from other favorites in the Green/Grant block of North Beach. We'll be back.

2q6xjhh5SAsqfV4qMCEErQ.review_text: Nice atmosphere, good service. Totally average to slightly below average food, but reasonable prices. In short, nothing to write home about.

dfYNTBw--CYlZbFz581kYQ.review_text: The food is decent, the wine is decent, the decor is decent, the service is decent, the experience is decent, the price is pretty reasonable... but Bocce is nothing special compared to many of its nearby North Beach neighbors. Think about Sodini's, DuPoint Thai, The House, El Raigon, Mangarosa, Joe DiMaggio's, etc before Bocce Cafe...

QXHnCf661Cccl4CSvuskqQ.review_text: I haven't been to this hidden place in North Beach in a couple years until yesterday and I forgot how much I missed it!  It's really great for large groups but be prepared to wait but you can grab a drink at the bar which can be fun.  On the the weekend evenings it usually gets pretty nuts in there but it's definitely well worth the wait if you want cheap, fast, good Italian food.  The first time I walked in the place I was blown away at how large the interior since the it's very deceiving from the outside.  There is an entire patio, a fairly large large casual dining area (some sections even have couches) and they even have a band playing at times which is kind of cheesy but whatever.  I can't recall a bad meal I've had there!

VygN3XApGokSlIocW1Uzrg.review_text: Whenever we're in North Beach & don't want to deal w/ the touristy restaurants we always end up dining at Bocce Cafe.  The place is like the North Beach's hidden gem.  Some of the booths are sofas & the price is definitely right.  The food is alright and so is the service.

aBfT6rp0tfhEyc7fWeuYJA.review_text: Eh.  Other than comfy chairs and live music and the leafy patio, there isn't much to recommend this place.  The service was incredibly slow.  We waited over a half hour to get our order taken.  The food, when it finally arrived, was not very good.  We had six people - three dishes came out.  We waited.  Two more dishes came out. We waited.  Our sixth person graciously insisted we start eating before it got cold.  His plate arrived five minutes later, with no explanation or apology for the delay.  Frankly, if they had never brought me my food, I'd have preferred it.  The chicken was overcooked, it was smothered in too much bad cheese and the sauce was so red it looked like they had dyed it.  It had very little flavor besides too much salt.  I don't know how they got away with getting $30 a piece out of us.

msOgATpeq7k14dQjUuL9iw.review_text: This was the worst chinese food I have ever had. Never knew chicken marsala was supposed to taste like teriyaki mushroom chicken. Tortellini sauce was like an expired version of ragu. Caprese mozzarella was over priced and bland, no oil or vinegar. The best thing about the whole experience was the mediocre wine, band, and not vomiting in the "garden" outside. This place needs a refresher course on Italian cuisine. Not worth it for the price or stomach ache. Worst Italian in the city... pepto is calling, til next time arrivederci

qHtzckFmtMDxtltxjTGXrA.review_text: If you like Italian food, try this place out.  It has a great, fun atmosphere, they do live music, the bar isn't bad(but it ain't great), outdoor patio... I was here with a bunch of friends and fams for dinner and we all had a good time....check it out and see for yourself, you'll be surprised.

P0B5h7QB6in5KglAmrmtAQ.review_text: one of my favorite restaurants in the city.  food is very good.  i like it so much that i had my wedding rehearsal dinner here a few years ago on the back patio.  they did an AMAZING job and set up an enclosed tent area ect.  friends and family out of town still talk about it.

Ud6j2HN40qEhycq2PuwcBA.review_text: As Hen A pointed out, this place sure reminded us of a lodge/cabin-like feel with the big rock walls, high ceiling, comfy cushion style seats/sofa-like and dim lighting....It was spacious and what a prime piece of property with outdoor patio seating but unfortunately, it was awfully quiet on a Sunday evening. We called ahead asking if we needed a reservation and we were told to just walk in. We saw the obvious when we arrived with only three other tables being filled, mind you, this is a bigger space restaurant.   As we were perusing the menu, we overheard our neighboring table sending back his lasagna which he deemed the content of his dish was cold and frozen! I FROZE at the thought of hearing that! I had a marvellous lasagna version at Ristorante Milano and would never attempt to diminish the good thoughts and experience so I vowed never to order lasagna in other locations and definitely not at Bocce. I signaled to bf NOT to order the lasagna, for obvious reasons!   Bf ordered the Margherita pizza - cheese and basil pizza and I had the Cioppino - crab, prawns, salmon, calamari, clams, and mussels in a marinara sauce, served in copper pot with pasta on the side. Yup, it sure came in a large copper pot, one that you'll find in your grandma's kitchen! I've never had it in a pot, it was usually served in a larger bowl. We had a good laugh as I started scooping out the content. It was a large portion considering that it came with a side of pasta dish! The soup was delicious and the mixture of seafood was decent.   We were glad that our entrees turned out decent but from the looks of other dishes and the dismay of other guests, I'm not sure if we'll return so soon with so many other Italian places to try in the city.

laJdnC21MrjWuAA6GcK04w.review_text: Very inviting and warm atmosphere. It's casual and cozy here, almost feel like home. My dining experience here wasn't a disappointment, the food was good, the portions were of just the right size and my server were helpful and genuine.

eZQC4Ng7NMKkOvBAdenbrw.review_text: I just wanted to put an update to my review.  I am still a big fan of Bocce and I want to thank them for helping me celebrate my brother's birthday.  The staff was nice and very patient with a crowd of 30 people.  The waitresses were helpful and fun and It just made the night great.  Everyone loved it.  GREAT FOR GROUPS!!!!!

sN6XqrVCINH-_fBbLiPleg.review_text: Bocce serves up your standard, albeit average, Italian fare in a unique open barn-like structure that you enter through a little path. The ambiance is neat, and it's great for large groups! The veggie lasagna was good, but perhaps a little too much tomato sauce. My partners Cappalini pomodoro was "good and fresh." Service was attentive and not overbearing. They were very kind enough to seat us before our entire party had arrived. I'll return, especially because it's quite affordable!

Xj0O2l0bp633ebmG468aZw.review_text: Good prices, simple/authentic food, a little bit dated decor. Easy to get into though -- especially considering the location.

HR1wozuAE_3KAHFP1XvIjw.review_text: We had dinner here this past Saturday night and it was the same lively, fun, casual atmosphere.  While there was no band this time around, good times were still had by all.  Instead of sitting inside, we were placed outside in an enclosed area.  For a moment, you forget that you're in San Francisco because it feels more like you're in a little Italy with the lighting and garden patio atmosphere.  (I've never been to Italy so this is probably a far fetched stretch of my imagination!)  I had the smoked salmon fettucini with pesto sauce and the salmon was a bit salty for my tastes.  The pesto sauce however was great.    Since we had a large party, we brought all of our own wine (around 12 bottles) and they do charge a corkage fee but it's much cheaper than buying theirs.

hdVwb3hKyUvLHcd7umBJ1Q.review_text: I'm going the full five kids!  We've eaten there twice now, in both a very large group, and a very small one.  Service was great both times.  The chicken picatta gets an +A.  It's served with yummy veggies, and small side of pasta marinara.  The pasta is always al dente, just the way I like.   The margarita pizza is very good too, as is anything served in their delicious creamy Alfredo sauce!  For dessert I've tried the creme caramel,  the chocolate cake and the spumoni.   All good, but their spumoni blew me away.  It was filled with large candied cherries and flavorful nuts. SO GOOD!!!  Finally, it's super CHEAP.  Every time we go we are blown away at how inexpensive our bill is, even with alcohol.  You must give this one a try!
